importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when former French President Nicolas Sarkozy is expected to begin serving his five-year prison sentence at La Santé prison in Paris.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-year prison sentence imposed on Sarkozy, beginning on October 20, 2025, places him in prison until October 20, 2026.

keyTakeAways: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has been convicted of criminal conspiracy related to financing his 2007 election campaign with funds from Libya.
Sarkozy maintains his innocence and has rejected the conviction, arguing it undermines democratic principles.
The Paris judge ruled that Sarkozy must begin serving his sentence immediately, without awaiting appeal, due to the seriousness of the offense and its disruption to public order.
Sarkozy will be held in La Santé prison, a high-profile institution with a long history of housing notable political and militant prisoners, including Capt. Alfred Dreyfus and Carlos the Jackal.
Sarkozy will serve his sentence in a 9-square-meter cell, possibly in the prison’s VIP section for vulnerable inmates, which provides a private room with fixed landline phones, but no incoming calls.
Sarkozy will be allowed to bring 10 family photos and three books, including 'The Count of Monte Cristo' and a biography of Jesus Christ.
He has expressed defiance, stating he will hold his head high and fight until the end, and will file an appeal only after entering prison, with a two-month processing window.
Former inmates, including Pierre Botton and Patrick Balkany, describe the psychological and physical shock of incarceration, noting the loss of status, privacy, and access to personal belongings.
The prison’s history and culture, including its treatment of high-profile inmates, may influence how Sarkozy experiences confinement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy is set to begin a five-year prison sentence at Paris’ La Santé prison on October 20, 2025, after being convicted of criminal conspiracy involving illegal campaign financing from Libya. Despite maintaining his innocence and protesting the decision, the judge ruled that he must serve the sentence immediately due to the severity of the offense and its disruption to public order. The prison, renowned for housing high-profile figures like Captain Dreyfus and Carlos the Jackal, will house Sarkozy in a small 9-square-meter cell, possibly in a VIP section with limited amenities. Former inmates such as Pierre Botton and Patrick Balkany describe the psychological and physical shock of incarceration, emphasizing the loss of status and privacy. Sarkozy will be allowed to bring 10 family photos and three books, including 'The Count of Monte Cristo' and a biography of Jesus Christ. He plans to file an appeal after entering prison, with a two-month processing window. The case marks a landmark moment in French political history, raising questions about the treatment of former leaders and the balance between accountability and personal liberty.
title: Former French President Sarkozy begins a 5-year prison sentence for campaign finance conspiracy
